subsection.title: Equivalent Expressions
subsection.p: When we solve an equation such as 2+3x=17 we find a value for the variable that makes the equation true. The solution to this equation is 5, because the two expressions 2+3x and 17 are equal if x=5. If we use any other value for x, say x=9 or x=-1, then 2+3x does not equal 17.

It is possible for two algebraic expressions to be equal for all values of the variable. For instance, the expressions 2x+3x and 5x will always give the same value when the same number is substituted for x in each expression. For example, \begin{aligned} \text{if}~~x=\alert{3}~~~~~\text{then}~~~~~~2x+3x \amp =2(\alert{3})+3(\alert{3})\\ \amp = 6+9=15\\ \text{and}~~~~~~5x \amp = 5(\alert{3})=15 \end{aligned} Both expressions equal 15 when x=3.

assemblage.p: Two algebraic expressions are equivalent if they name the same number for all values of the variable.

subsection.p: Thus, 2+3x and 5x are equivalent expressions, and we can replace one by the other if it will simplify our work.

answer.p: When they name the same number for all values of the variable.

subsection.title: Like Terms
subsection.p: We saw above that 2x+3x and 5x are equivalent expressions. This makes sense when we consider what these expressions mean: 2x means two x's added together, and 3x means three x's added together. Then 2x+3x=(x+x)+(x+x+x)=5x We can add two x's to three x's and get five x's, just as we can add two pencils to three pencils, or two dollars to three dollars. In algebra this is called combining like terms.

assemblage.p: Like terms are any terms that are exactly alike in their variable factors.

ol.label: a

assemblage.p: The numerical factor in a term is called the numerical coefficient, or just the coefficient of the term.

ol.label: a
ol.li: In the expression 3xy, the number 3 is the numerical coefficient.
In a term such as xy or b, the numerical coefficient is 1.

subsection.title: Adding and Subtracting Like Terms

assemblage.title: To add like terms
assemblage.p: Add the numerical coefficients of the terms. Do not change the variable factors of the terms.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: In Example 3, we replaced each expression by a simpler but equivalent expression. In other words, -7y is equivalent to -4t-3y, and 3st is equivalent to -6st+9st.
Replacing an expression by a simpler equivalent one is called simplifying the expression.

subsection.p: We subtract like terms in the same way that we add like terms.

assemblage.title: To subtract like terms
assemblage.p: Subtract the numerical coefficients of the terms. Do not change the variable factors of the terms.

answer.p: Any terms that are exactly alike in their variable factors.

statement.p: How do we add or subtract like terms?

answer.p: Add or subtract the numerical coefficients of the terms.

subsection.p: Many expressions contain both like and unlike terms. In such expressions we can combine only the like terms.

solution.p: We combine all the a-terms, and all the constant terms, like this: -4a+8a+5a=9a ~~~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~~~2-5=-3 so -4a+2-5+8a+5a=9a-3

warning.p: In Example 5, 9a-4 \not= 6a, because 9a and -3 are not like terms.

subsection.title: Removing Parentheses
subsection.p: When we add signed numbers, we can remove parentheses that follow an addition symbol. For instance, 5+(-3)=5-3=2 We can also remove parentheses when we add like terms. Thus, 5x+(-3x)=5x-3x=2x

assemblage.title: Removing parentheses that follow a plus sign
assemblage.p: Parentheses preceded by a plus sign may be omitted, and each term within parentheses keeps its original sign.

subsection.p: BUT: We must be careful when removing parentheses preceded by a minus sign. In the expression (5x-2)-(7x-4) the minus sign preceding (7x-4) applies to each term inside the parentheses. Therefore, when we remove the parentheses we must change the sign of 7x from + to - and we must change the sign of -4 from - to +. Thus, \begin{aligned} (5x-2)-(7x-4)\amp = 5x-2-7x+4 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Change each sign inside parentheses.}}\\ \amp =5x-7x-2+4 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Combine like terms.}}\\ \amp =-2x+2 \end{aligned}

assemblage.title: Removing parentheses that follow a minus sign
assemblage.p: If an expression inside parentheses is preceded by a minus sign, we change the sign of each term within parentheses and then omit the parentheses and the minus sign.

answer.p: Change the sign of each term within parentheses.

subsection.title: Solving Equations and Inequalities
subsection.p: We can now solve equations in which two or more terms contain the variable.
If one side of an equation or inequality contains like terms, we should combine them before beginning to solve.

statement.p: What should you do if one side of an equation or inequality contains like terms?

subsection.p: Here are our guidelines for solving linear equations.

ol.li: Combine like terms on each side of the equation.
By adding or subtracting the same quantity on both sides of the equation, get all the variable terms on one side and all the constant terms on the other.
Divide both sides by the coefficient of the variable to obtain an equation of the form x=a.
